text: Full list of error types + minimal pairs (for a grammar checker aimed at C1 L1 Cantonese speakers, casual & professional). Format: Error type — short description.Minimal pair(s): incorrect → correctedAction: (a) must flag and explain — explains why & how to fix; (b) must only flag — mark as likely issue (no long explanation), e.g., purely stylistic or low-priority. Note: You asked “DO NOT ANALYSIS” — below is a direct, comprehensive catalogue (no meta-analysis). 1. Articles & determiners Omission of definite/indefinite article (a/an/the) Minimal pairs: I bought book yesterday. → I bought a book yesterday. Action: (a) Wrong article choice (a vs an) Minimal pairs: an university → a university Action: (a) Overuse of the with general nouns Minimal pairs: The love is important. → Love is important. Action: (a) Unnecessary article before uncountables or plurals Minimal pairs: a information → information ; the cars are expensive (when speaking generally) → cars are expensive Action: (a) Determiner omission with possessives / demonstratives Minimal pairs: This car is mine. vs This is mine. (flag if missing demonstrative) Action: (a) 2. Countable / uncountable nouns & pluralization Missing plural -s Minimal pairs: three person → three people ; I have many homework. → I have much homework / a lot of homework. Action: (a) Incorrect singular/plural agreement with quantifiers Minimal pairs: many advices → much advice / many pieces of advice Action: (a) Wrong classifier-like translations (Cantonese L1 interference) Minimal pairs: two informations → two pieces of information Action: (a) 3. Subject–verb agreement Number/person mismatch Minimal pairs: He go to work. → He goes to work. Action: (a) Agreement with collective nouns (depends on register) Minimal pairs: The team are winning. → The team is winning. (flag as register option) Action: (b) 4. Tense & aspect (time reference) Wrong tense for time frame (past/present/future confusion) Minimal pairs: Yesterday I go to market. → Yesterday I went to the market. Action: (a) Progressive vs simple aspect errors Minimal pairs: I study now. → I am studying now. ; I am knowing him. → I know him. Action: (a) Present perfect misuse vs simple past (since/for / already / yet) Minimal pairs: I have seen him yesterday. → I saw him yesterday. ; I saw him since 2019. → I have seen him since 2019. Action: (a) Perfect continuous misuse Minimal pairs: I have been knowing him for years. → I have known him for years. Action: (a) Future forms misuse (will vs going to vs present continuous) Minimal pairs: I will meeting her tonight. → I'm meeting her tonight. ; It will rain tomorrow. vs It's going to rain. (flag usage) Action: (a) 5. Modals & auxiliaries Wrong modal selection (can/could/will/would/shall/should/must/might) Minimal pairs: Can you pass me the salt? (casual) vs Could you pass me the salt? (polite) Action: (a) Omission of auxiliary in questions/negatives Minimal pairs: You coming? → Are you coming? ; He not agree. → He does not agree. Action: (a) Double auxiliary or auxiliary errors (do + modal) Minimal pairs: Does he can come? → Can he come? Action: (a) 6. Passive voice errors Incorrect passive formation / omitted agent where needed Minimal pairs: The letter wrote by Mary. → The letter was written by Mary. Action: (a) Unnecessary passive in casual contexts (register) Minimal pairs: Mistakes were made. (formal) → I made a mistake. (if clarifying responsibility) Action: (b) 7. Conditionals & hypothetical structures Wrong conditional type or tense Minimal pairs: If I will see him, I tell him. → If I see him, I'll tell him. ; If I had known, I would go. → If I had known, I would have gone. Action: (a) Mixed conditional errors Minimal pairs: If I were rich, I would travel next year. → If I were rich, I would travel now. / or adjust tense appropriately. Action: (a) 8. Relative clauses & relative pronouns Omission/misuse of who/which/that/where/when/whose Minimal pairs: The man which spoke to me. → The man who spoke to me. Action: (a) Restrictive vs non-restrictive punctuation and pronoun choice Minimal pairs: My sister, who lives in London works here. → My sister, who lives in London, works here. (commas) Action: (a) 9. Pronouns & reference Incorrect subject/object pronoun Minimal pairs: Me and him went. → He and I went. ; Give it to I. → Give it to me. Action: (a) Ambiguous or missing referent (pronoun reference) Minimal pairs: John told Dave that he was wrong. → John told Dave, “You were wrong,” or John told Dave that Dave was wrong. (clarify) Action: (a) Possessive vs contraction confusion Minimal pairs: Its a problem. → It's a problem. ; The dog wagged it's tail. → The dog wagged its tail. Action: (a) 10. Gerunds & infinitives Wrong choice: gerund vs infinitive after certain verbs/adjectives Minimal pairs: I suggested to go. → I suggested going. ; I want studying. → I want to study. Action: (a) 11. Adjectives & adverbs Confusing adjective/adverb forms Minimal pairs: He speaks good. → He speaks well. ; A quickly reply → A quick reply. Action: (a) Adjective order errors (opinion-size-age-shape-color-origin-material-purpose) Minimal pairs: a red big car → a big red car Action: (a) Using very with ungradable adjectives (absolute adjectives) Minimal pairs: very unique → unique / truly unique Action: (b) 12. Comparative & superlative forms Wrong comparative/superlative formation or irregular forms Minimal pairs: more better → better ; gooder → better ; the most funniest → the funniest Action: (a) Comparative clause errors (than vs as) Minimal pairs: She is taller then me. → She is taller than me. ; He is as tall then I am. → as tall as I am. Action: (a) 13. Prepositions Incorrect preposition choice (at/in/on/by/for/to/with/of/about/from/into/onto) Minimal pairs: I will meet you in 5pm. → at 5pm. ; I am good in tennis. → good at tennis. ; She arrived to Hong Kong. → arrived in Hong Kong. Action: (a) Preposition omission Minimal pairs: I wait the bus. → I waited for the bus. Action: (a) Confusion with phrasal-prepositional differences (in/on/at the weekend) Minimal pairs: on the weekend (US) vs at the weekend (BrE) — flag regional choice. Action: (b) 14. Word order & sentence structure Adverb placement (frequency/time manner) Minimal pairs: I often go sometimes. → I sometimes go. ; He speaks English well always. → He always speaks English well. Action: (a) Incorrect negative word order Minimal pairs: I not can go. → I cannot / can't go. Action: (a) Topic-prominent transfer from Cantonese: fronting or lack of subject Minimal pairs: This book I finished. → I finished this book. (acceptable in some contexts but flag for register/clarity) Action: (b) 15. Conjunctions & connectors Run-ons / comma splices (missing coordination/subordination) Minimal pairs: I was tired, I went to bed. → I was tired, so I went to bed. or I was tired; I went to bed. Action: (a) Subordinator misuse in reason/result (because / so / therefore) Minimal pairs: Because he was old, he died. (grammatical but can be style) vs He died because he was old. (flag causal clarity) Action: (b) 16. Sentence fragments & run-ons Incomplete sentences (missing subject/verb) Minimal pairs: When we arrived. → When we arrived, the show had started. or We arrived. Action: (a) Run-on sentences Minimal pairs: She likes apples she eats them. → She likes apples; she eats them. Action: (a) 17. Punctuation Comma misuse or omission (lists, clauses, non-restrictive clauses) Minimal pairs: My teacher John is here. → My teacher, John, is here. (if non-restrictive) Action: (a) Apostrophe misuse for possession vs contractions Minimal pairs: The teachers lounge → The teachers' lounge (if plural possessive) ; it's temperature → its temperature Action: (a) Semicolon/colon misuse Minimal pairs: He had one goal: to win (correct) vs He had one goal; to win (incorrect) Action: (b) 18. Capitalization & orthography Improper capitalization Minimal pairs: i live in hong kong. → I live in Hong Kong. Action: (b) Spelling errors, homophone confusion Minimal pairs: their/there/they're ; affect / effect ; advise / advice ; accept / except ; borrow / lend ; bring / take Action: (a) 19. Collocations and lexical selection Incorrect collocations (common verb + noun pairs) Minimal pairs: make a decision vs do a decision → do → make Action: (a) False friends / direct translation errors from Cantonese Minimal pairs: open the light → turn on the light ; long time no see (casual OK) → It's been a long time since we last met. (professional) Action: (a) 20. Register, tone, and politeness (casual vs professional) Overly literal or informally direct phrasing in professional contexts Minimal pairs: Give me the report. → Could you send me the report, please? Action: (a) (explain difference) Excessive hedging or lack thereof (affects persuasion & politeness) Minimal pairs: This is wrong. → I think there might be an issue with this. (flag register) Action: (b) 21. Hedging, mitigation, and pragmatic markers Missing hedging leading to blunt statements Minimal pairs: You're wrong. → I think there's a problem here. Action: (b) 22. Discourse & cohesion problems Missing linking expressions (however, moreover, therefore) causing incoherent flow Minimal pairs: He studied. He failed. → He studied hard; however, he failed. Action: (b) 23. Reported speech / backshifting Failure to backshift tenses in reported speech Minimal pairs: He said, “I am tired.” → He said he is tired. → He said he was tired. (depending on context) Action: (a) 24. Tag questions & question forms Incorrect tag formation Minimal pairs: You are coming, isn't it? → You're coming, aren't you? Action: (a) 25. Negation & double negatives Double negation or wrong negative polarity Minimal pairs: I didn't see nothing. → I didn't see anything. Action: (a) 26. Fixed phrases, idioms & register-appropriate idiomatic usage Incorrect idiom or literal translation Minimal pairs: break a rice → break a leg (idiom misuse) Action: (b) 27. Adjective order & multiple modifiers Incorrect stacking of multiple adjectives Minimal pairs: a cotton small red shirt → a small red cotton shirt Action: (a) 28. Numerals & quantifiers, percentages Wrong use of articles/numbers with percent/measure phrases Minimal pairs: A 50% of people → 50% of people ; a half of the students → half of the students / a half (context) Action: (a) 29. Phrasal verbs and separable/inseparable distinctions Wrong particle placement or wrong particle Minimal pairs: turn the lights off vs turn off the lights (both okay if separable) ; look after vs look for confusion: I look after my keys. → I look for my keys. Action: (a) 30. Redundancy & pleonasm Unnecessary duplication (e.g., revert back, past history) Minimal pairs: revert back → revert ; advance planning → planning Action: (b) 31. Ellipsis & omitted elements (under-specified) Missing necessary elements in professional writing (subject, verb, object) Minimal pairs: If required, contact. → If required, contact me/us at... Action: (a) 32. Emphasis & cleft sentences Incorrect cleft formation or emphasis Minimal pairs: It is John who I met. → correct cleft: It was John whom I met. (depends on focus) Action: (b) 33. Errors typical from Cantonese L1 interference (explicit list) Omission of copula "be" Minimal pairs: He tall. → He is tall. Action: (a) Omission of plural marking, articles, tense morphology Minimal pairs: I go school yesterday. → I went to school yesterday. Action: (a) Direct translation of classifiers / measure words Minimal pairs: three person → three people ; two piece of advice → two pieces of advice Action: (a) Topic-prominent word order: fronting topic without subject–verb inversion Minimal pairs: This cake, I like. → I like this cake. (flag for register/closeness to Cantonese) Action: (b) 34. Sentence-level pragmatic errors (impoliteness / bluntness) Imperative forms lacking politeness in professional email Minimal pairs: Send the report. → Please send the report. or Could you send the report? Action: (a) 35. Minimal pairs of commonly confused words (lexical confusions) — must be detected Homophones & near-homophones Minimal pairs: their / there / they're — Action: (a) affect / effect — Action: (a) advise / advice — Action: (a) accept / except — Action: (a) borrow / lend — Action: (a) bring / take — Action: (a) rise / raise — Action: (a) fewer / less — Minimal pairs: fewer people vs less water — Action: (a) amount / number — Action: (a) since / for — Minimal pairs: since 2019 vs for two years — Action: (a) already / yet — Minimal pairs: Have you finished yet? / I have already finished. — Action: (a) 36. Pragmatic/semantic errors that change meaning Using verbs that change valency (transitive vs intransitive) incorrectly Minimal pairs: He arrived the station. → He arrived at the station. ; She broke the vase. (active vs She was broken.) Action: (a) Using wrong argument structure (forget vs remind vs remember) Minimal pairs: Please remind me to call. vs I forgot to call. — Action: (a) 37. Professional writing conventions Inappropriate contractions in formal register Minimal pairs: Can't / won't in formal email → cannot / will not (flag register) Action: (b) Bulleted lists punctuation & parallelism errors Minimal pairs: - to write reports - checking emails - meeting clients → make all verbs parallel: writing, checking, meeting Action: (b) 38. Common punctuation-in-Asian-language-transfer issues Full-width punctuation vs ASCII (presentation) Minimal pairs: Chinese full-width comma used in English sentence → flag for typographic correctness. Action: (b) Prioritization guidance (how checker should behave overall) Always provide (a) explanations for: articles, tense/aspect, subject–verb agreement, countable/uncountable, pronouns, prepositions, modal misuse, conditionals, gerund/infinitive errors, comparative/superlative, passive formation, punctuation that affects meaning (commas, apostrophes), lexical confusables (their/there/etc.), collocations that change meaning, and Cantonese-L1 interference errors listed above. Flag-only (b) for lower-priority or stylistic issues: register choices, regional preposition variants, adjective gradability style choices (very unique), punctuation style (semicolon vs colon), typography/full-width characters, and certain discourse-level cohesion problems unless they block comprehension. If you want, I can now convert this catalogue into (pick one): a compact rule-set for an automatic checker (regex + priority + brief fix suggestion), example error messages and short learner-facing explanations per rule, or a prioritized test-suite of minimal-pair sentences for evaluation. Which format do you want next? Top of Form Bottom of Form ChatGPT can make mistakes. Check important info.
